radio_episode.description: Why is it always harder than you think it'll be? We explore several case examples of the annoying gap between theory and practice.

radio_episode.title: Garbage
radio_episode.description: We make what's usually invisible, visible: the world of trash. We follow the trash from the sanitation men on the street, to the mob guys who controlled the hauling business, to the people who actually live in dumps.

radio_episode.title: Like It or Not
radio_episode.description: Some stories we make happen, others happen to us. Extremes from the latter category, where people let things happen to them and don't act, even when maybe they should. David Rakoff guest hosts.

radio_episode.title: What Is This Thing?
radio_episode.description: What is this thing? This thing called love, that is. For answers, we explore the romance novel industry, a $1.5 billion empire run almost entirely by and for women. Plus, relearning the rules of romance from the other side of the gender line. And Sarah Vowell tells the story of the Greatest Romance of the 20th Century.

radio_episode.title: My Pen Pal
radio_episode.description: Stories of very unusual pen pals, people whose relationship could not exist without the help of the postal service.

radio_episode.title: Allure of the Mean Friend
radio_episode.description: What is it about them, our mean friends? They treat us badly, they don't call us back, they cancel plans at the last minute, and yet we come back for more. Popular bullies exist in business, politics, everywhere. How do they stay so popular?

radio_episode.title: MacGyver
radio_episode.description: In real life, we usually never get to invent ingenious solutions, like the guy in the old TV series MacGyver. Today, four real stories in which real people invent amazingly clever solutions to their problems.

radio_episode.title: Later That Same Day
radio_episode.description: Stories about what the passage of time can do to someone. When each story starts, the world's aligned one way. Years pass—or sometimes just months—and everything's different.

radio_episode.title: Enemy Camp
radio_episode.description: Living behind enemy lines among the enemy, it's sometimes hard to remember why you're fighting in the first place.

radio_episode.title: 20 Acts in 60 Minutes
radio_episode.description: Instead of the usual "each week we choose a theme, and bring you 3 or 4 stories on that theme" business, we throw all that away and bring you 20 stories—yes, 20—in 60 minutes.

radio_episode.title: I'm In Charge Now
radio_episode.description: Stories of people putting themselves in charge in very unlikely, unpromising circumstances.

radio_episode.title: Lost in America
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who are lost, histories that are lost, and things that are lost. This show was recorded onstage in front of audiences on a five-city tour in May 2003. The cities: Boston, Washington DC, Portland Oregon, Denver and Chicago. Featuring house band OK Go.

radio_episode.title: Lost in Translation
radio_episode.description: Stories of what can and cannot be translated. A short, non-athletic, bespectacled East Asian studies major who couldn't make his high school basketball team finds himself in the NBA as the personal translator for the first-ever Chinese pro basketball superstar, Yao Ming. Plus, a Palestinian man teaches Hebrew classes in the Gaza strip to Palestinians eager to learn news from the other side of the checkpoint.

radio_episode.title: Regime Change
radio_episode.description: Sure, John Kerry got in trouble for using the phrase, but we have no fear. Because we know that regime change, like charity, begins at home.  This week: Stories of regime change in everyday life—people switching jobs, people switching families, businesses dying and new ones starting in their place.

radio_episode.title: My Two Cents
radio_episode.description: Stories from a contradictory recession. (Audio is from the updated 2004 broadcast)

radio_episode.title: The Balloon Goes Up
radio_episode.description: Stories from the beginnings of the war in Iraq, and how it compares with wars in our country's past.

radio_episode.title: Say Anything
radio_episode.description: Does talking about it really help? Stories where it does, and stories where it doesn't, including Michael Bernard Loggins, who tried to battle his fears by listing them. He ended up with a list 183 items long.

radio_episode.title: Starting from Scratch
radio_episode.description: Stories of people starting over, sometimes because they want to, other times because they have to.

radio_episode.title: The Real Story
radio_episode.description: It's been said that truth is the first casualty of war. In this week's show, we try to get the real stories from three very different wars.

radio_episode.title: Time to Save the World
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to save the world one person at a time, and stories of sudden truths delivered by complete strangers.

radio_episode.title: Come Back to Afghanistan
radio_episode.description: In January 2002, the President of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzai, spoke at Georgetown University. There he urged Afghan-Americans, especially young ones, to move back to Afghanistan.

radio_episode.title: Secret Government
radio_episode.description: Stories of some of the secrets our government keeps: of imprisonment, deportation, and spying, and how those secrets affect us.

radio_episode.title: You Are So Beautiful…To Me
radio_episode.description: Two stories about love, and what people mean when they use the word love. Or, looked at differently, two modern-day reinterpretations of the Frog Prince story. One concerns a pretty man falling in love with an unlikely woman. And an unlikely woman falling in love with a pretty bird.

radio_episode.title: Why We Fight
radio_episode.description: Stories about why we should go to war versus stories of why we shouldn't.

radio_episode.title: Reruns
radio_episode.description: Stories of people stuck in their own personal reruns—moments or episodes that they revisit over and over again.    You can watch an animated version of Robert Krulwich's Jackie O story from this episode.

radio_episode.title: Home Movies
radio_episode.description: Home movies are often all the same—kids on the beach, people getting married, birthday parties—so why do we make and watch so many of them? Maybe it's because the story they show and the story they tell are different. In this show, we bring you five stories that all start with a fairly typical home movie but go on to tell a unique story.

radio_episode.title: Middlemen
radio_episode.description: In this week's show, we celebrate the oft-beleaguered and misrepresented middleman. "Cut out the middleman! Death to the middleman!" the angry hordes cry. Not us. We say, "Hi, middleman. Here are three splendid acts to toast your subtle virtues."

radio_episode.title: Classifieds
radio_episode.description: In this show we take the classifieds from one Sunday edition of the Chicago Sun-Times and one edition of the local alternative weekly Chicago Reader, and fill a program with stories that come from the ads. Through the jobs offered, the missed connections, the crap that people sell each other and the musicians' ads we get a portrait of a whole city.

radio_episode.title: Suckers
radio_episode.description: Some people have a rather dark worldview that divides people into two groups: Suckers and non-suckers. We hear their stories.

radio_episode.title: Fake I.D.
radio_episode.description: Stories of people traveling under fake papers, false identities, not for power or personal gain, but for their own deeper personal reasons.

radio_episode.title: Testosterone
radio_episode.description: Stories of people getting more testosterone and coming to regret it. And of people losing it and coming to appreciate life without it. The pros and cons of the hormone of desire.

radio_episode.title: High Speed Chase
radio_episode.description: Stories of innocent people fleeing from dangerous men in cars who shoot at them. Unlike in the movies, the pursuers aren't foreign agents or rogue CIA agents, but drunk off-duty policemen and small-town teenagers. Real-ife high-speed chases: who gets chased...and who does the chasing.

radio_episode.title: Act V
radio_episode.description: We devote this entire episode to one story: Over the course of six months, reporter and TAL contributor Jack Hitt followed a group of inmates at a high-security prison as they rehearsed and staged a production of the last act—Act V—of Hamlet.

radio_episode.title: Give It to Them
radio_episode.description: It's been two years since the Mideast peace process collapsed, two years in which each side has done terrible things to the other side. We wanted to understand what that has done to people living in Israel and the West Bank, and to see if anyone is feeling hope.

radio_episode.title: Give the People What They Want
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who go to great lengths to give people what they want, and how they're rewarded sometimes, misguided other times.

radio_episode.title: Ask An Expert
radio_episode.description: Stories about people who turned to the experts and got horrible advice. One story is about people who went to therapists who made them sicker. Another is about how the hosts of Car Talk inadvertently (or perhaps intentionally) destroyed a car belonging to one of their own employees.

radio_episode.title: Family Physics
radio_episode.description: We take the stately laws of physics—laws which mathematicians and scientists have spent centuries discovering and verifying—and apply them to the realm of human relationships, to see if they shed useful light on our daily lives.

radio_episode.title: Devil on My Shoulder
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who are trying to convince you that the Devil is there, whispering in your ear...and stories of people who try to deny he's there, against some very heavy evidence.

radio_episode.title: The Other Man
radio_episode.description: Stories about what happens when a new guy comes on the scene, and changes the way everyone who was already there relates to each other.

radio_episode.title: Naming Names
radio_episode.description: Stories about what happens when you name names. When you turn someone over to the authorities, it can set into motion lots of huge, unintended consequences. A reporter turns over an interviewee to the FBI. A group of teachers turn in their principal. A director turns in his Communist colleagues to the United States Congress.

radio_episode.title: Perfect Evidence
radio_episode.description: After a decade in which DNA evidence has freed over 100 people nationwide, it's become clear that DNA evidence isn't just proving wrongdoing by criminals, it's proving wrongdoing by police and prosecutors. In this show, we look at what DNA has revealed to us: how police get innocent people to confess to crimes they didn't commit and how they get witnesses to pin crimes on innocent people.

radio_episode.title: Didn't Ask to Be Born
radio_episode.description: Two stories that are worst case scenarios for any parent. In each story, when you take apart what happened and how it happened, it's hard to see how anyone could've prevented things from going bad.

radio_episode.title: Office Politics
radio_episode.description: Stories of high drama from our nation's workplaces. They turn out to be surprising, emotional places, with all the greed, jealousy, and ambition of real politics.

radio_episode.title: Special Ed
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Susan Harrington, one of the reporters featured in the documentary How's Your News?
radio_episode.description: Stories about people who were told that they're different. Some of them were comfortable with it. Some didn't understand it. And some understood, but didn't like it.

radio_episode.title: Somewhere in the Arabian Sea
radio_episode.description: Life aboard the USS John C. Stennis, an aircraft carrier that was stationed in the Arabian Sea and supported bombing missions over Afghanistan. Only a few dozen people on board actually fly jets. It takes the rest of the crew — over 5,000 people — to keep them in the air. This American Life producers visited the Stennis in 2002, about six weeks into its deployment. The hour is devoted to this one story.

radio_episode.title: Plan B
radio_episode.description: There's the thing you plan to do, and then there's the thing you end up doing. Most of us start off our lives with some Plan A which we abandon...switching to a Plan B, which becomes our life.

radio_episode.title: 81 Words
radio_episode.description: The story of how the American Psychiatric Association decided in 1973 that homosexuality was no longer a mental illness.

radio_episode.title: Recordings for Someone
radio_episode.description: All the stories in this week's show center on personal recordings that one person made for just one other person.

radio_episode.title: Faith
radio_episode.description: Stories of faith: losing it, talking about it, constructing it, and working within it.

radio_episode.title: Them
radio_episode.description: In a time of war, when we're all feeling a heightened sense of "us" and "them," we wanted to take up the problem of "them." Some people need a good "them." Other people tend to see all "thems" as more like us. And so we bring you three stories of people misperceiving the them-miness of them.

radio_episode.title: Hearts and Minds
radio_episode.description: Of all the wars to win, perhaps the propaganda war is the hardest. In this show, we bring you stories of propaganda wars past and present, by those who fought them and those who survived them.

radio_episode.title: House on Loon Lake
radio_episode.description: Our entire show this week is one long story, sort of a real-life Hardy Boys mystery. More than most of our shows, this one lends itself to a Hollywood-style tagline. Perhaps: "You Might Break In...But You'll Never Forget." Or "Dead Letters Tell No Tales."

radio_episode.title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
radio_episode.description: Stories of people climbing to be number one. How do they do it? What is the fundamental difference between us and them?

radio_episode.title: Before It Had A Name
radio_episode.description: There's the time when you know something is happening, but you're not sure exactly what. The illness before it's diagnosed. The era, before it's been given a title. And something changes when the name is given. Stories of that transformation...between what it is now, and what it was before it had a name.

radio_episode.title: Rashomon
radio_episode.description: In the movie Rashomon, one story is told from four different points of view. The story changes dramatically depending on who's telling it. This week, the events of September 11th, and how their meaning changes depending on who you talk to.

radio_episode.title: War Stories
radio_episode.description: In September 2001, we tried to sort out what the war in Afghanistan would be like, and what our lives would be like during this war.

radio_episode.title: Before and After
radio_episode.description: Stories in the wake of the events of September 11, 2001.

radio_episode.title: Stories of Loss
radio_episode.description: In the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, a collection of stories in which people try to make sense of loss.

radio_episode.title: Meet the Pros
radio_episode.description: The story of one man's journey from obscurity to international professional celebrity—aided only by his own hard work, a sneaker commercial, and mad handles. And other stories of amateurs hurtling themselves at the pros whose jobs they covet.

radio_episode.title: I Know What You Did This Summer
radio_episode.description: Stories for the stultifying, torpor-inducing, hottest heat of summer.

radio_episode.title: Living the Dream
radio_episode.description: There's a deep impulse in American culture that says that you can make yourself into anyone. Today, three stories about people who tried to do just that.

radio_episode.title: Hitler's Yacht
radio_episode.description: Nearly this entire show is devoted to the story of the boat known as "Hitler's Yacht." It's a modern-day fable about what happens when the free market, the media, the World War II buffs, the Neo-Nazis, and the Jews all collide over a huge Nazi tourist trap.

radio_episode.title: Kid Logic
radio_episode.description: Stories of kids using perfectly logical arguments, and arriving at perfectly wrong conclusions.

radio_episode.title: Father's Day '01
radio_episode.description: For Father's Day, stories of dads who are utterly human in scale.

radio_episode.title: Prom
radio_episode.description: While the seniors danced at Prom Night 2001 in Hoisington, Kansas—a town of about 3,000—a tornado hit the town, destroying about a third of it. When they emerged from the dance, they discovered what had happened, and in the weeks that followed, they tried to explain to themselves why the tornado hit where it did. Plus other stories that happen on Prom Night.

radio_episode.title: Golden Calf
radio_episode.description: Stories of people worshiping false idols...and if that's always a bad thing.

radio_episode.title: Neighbors
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to love their neighbors...and failing.

radio_episode.title: The Missing Parents Bureau
radio_episode.description: Stories about the legacy of absent parents. We hear four cases from the files of the Missing Parents Bureau.

radio_episode.title: Cringe
radio_episode.description: Stories that make us cringe, and an investigation into just what, exactly, makes some stories capable of forcing this physical reaction out of us when other stories don't. We hear tales of personal humiliation, romance gone wrong, and people who profoundly misjudge how they're perceived by others.

radio_episode.title: The Friendly Man
radio_episode.description: A special show, composed entirely of stories from just one This American Life contributor: Scott Carrier, whose strange and compelling stories sound like nothing else on the radio.

radio_episode.title: Return to Childhood
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who try to revisit their childhoods. What they find. And what they do not find.

radio_episode.title: Cicero
radio_episode.description: The story in a way of a town that time forgot, or more accurately, a town that tried to forget the times. A special broadcast co-hosted by award-winning journalist Alex Kotlowitz, author of the books There Are No Children Here and The Other Side of the River.

radio_episode.title: Superpowers
radio_episode.description: We answer the following questions about superpowers: Can superheroes be real people? (No.) Can real people become superheroes? (Maybe.) And which is better: flight or invisibility? (Depends who you ask.)    Chris ware's comic mentioned in the episode is here.

radio_episode.title: American Limbo
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: An interpretation of Limbo, as described in Dante's 'Divine Comedy'
radio_episode.description: Stories of people living completely outside the grid of American life. Americans in Paris. Chinese in America. West Virginians in treehouses. Mexican-Americans in Rochester.

radio_episode.title: Two Nations, One President
radio_episode.description: In the wake of the 2001 election debacle in Florida, the two political halves of this country seemed angrier at each other than they had in decades. This week we bring you tales of that widening rift. Democrats explain why they're having trouble getting over it, and Republicans explain why this is so infuriating.

radio_episode.title: Babysitting
radio_episode.description: Stories of babysitters, and what goes on while mom and dad are away that mom and dad never find out about. Including the story of two teenagers who decide to invent children to babysit, as an excuse to get out of their own house.

radio_episode.title: Birthdays, Anniversaries, and Milestones
radio_episode.description: Birthdays, anniversaries, and milestones of all sorts...and how they mean something whether we want them to or not. A live show taped for our fifth anniversary, back in 2000, when we went on the road to Boston, New York, Chicago, and L.A. Featuring house band OK Go.

radio_episode.title: Three Kinds of Deception
radio_episode.description: A story of self-deception, a story about deceiving others, and a story about accidental deception. And how one type of deception can easily turn into another.

radio_episode.title: 24 Hours at the Golden Apple
radio_episode.description: The This American Life producers document one day in a Chicago diner called The Golden Apple, starting at 5 a.m. and going until 5 a.m. the next morning. We hear from the waitress who has worked the graveyard shift for over two decades, the regular customers who come every day, the couples working out their problems, various assorted drunks, and, of course, cops.

radio_episode.title: Election
radio_episode.description: Stories for the eve of the Presidential election, in which we try to evade, sidestep or look beneath the candidates' soundbites.

radio_episode.title: Immigration
radio_episode.description: We live in a big enough country that there are lots of laws too obscure for most of us to have heard of...but which actually affect tens of thousands of lives in huge ways. This show deals with one of them: A 1996 immigration law that the Immigration Service itself says is unfair.

radio_episode.title: Pursuit of Happiness
radio_episode.description: We as a nation declared our independence based on, among other things, the right to pursue our happiness. But what does it mean, over two centuries later, to grow up in a country with an inalienable right to pursue happiness? Stories of people pursuing happiness, and sometimes, achieving it.

radio_episode.title: The Fix Is In
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Image of Mark Whitacre by Jacob Willis of Bauman Photographers.
radio_episode.description: There are all sorts of situations in which we suspect the fix is in, but we almost never find out for certain. On today's show, for once, we find out.

radio_episode.title: Memo to the People of the Future
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who are engaged in something that's both difficult and probably futile: Trying to control how they'll be seen by generations to come.

radio_episode.title: Nobody's Family Is Going to Change
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Julia Pimsleur, from Act One, with her brother.
radio_episode.description: Three stories that consider the question: Does anyone's family ever change?

radio_episode.title: Americans In Paris
radio_episode.description: Many Americans have dreamy and romantic ideas about Paris, notions which probably trace back to the 1920s vision of Paris created by the expatriate Americans there. But what's it actually like in Paris if you're an American, without rose-colored glasses?

radio_episode.title: Crime Scene
radio_episode.description: Every crime scene hides a story. In this week's show, we hear about crime scenes and the stories they tell.

radio_episode.title: Can You Fight City Hall…If You Are City Hall?
radio_episode.description: Stories of a typically American kind of hero: The person who decides to fight city hall, who stands up alone for what's right, and damn the consequences.

radio_episode.title: Moving
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who did not want to move but circumstance forced their hands, and so they tried to move without really moving.

radio_episode.title: Million Bubbles
radio_episode.description: Imagine that you could somehow look down from above, onto all the streets and avenues and country roads and highways of this nation...each car below its own tiny subculture on wheels...glass and steel worlds rolling down the street alongside each other. We hear what's going on inside some of these cars.

radio_episode.title: Character Assassination
radio_episode.description: In context of the Presidential contest between George W. Bush and Al Gore, we hear stories of character assassination...political and non-political.

radio_episode.title: Mother's Day
radio_episode.description: Stories of moms: How they treat us, how we treat them.

radio_episode.title: Mob Mentality
radio_episode.description: The pleasure of being in a rampaging, angry mob...and the terror of being in a rampaging, angry mob.

radio_episode.title: Secret Life of Daytime
radio_episode.description: All those people you see in the middle of the workday, in coffee shops and bookstores? Who are they? Why aren't they at work?

radio_episode.title: What Remains
radio_episode.description: Usually This American Life brings you stories of people in the middle of big experiences. But sometimes these moments of dramatic change are only half the story. The other half occurs after time passes and they return to revisit what happened, and who they were back when. Today's show is about what they find.

radio_episode.title: Hoaxing Yourself
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who tell a lie and then believe the lie more than anyone else does. In other words: Stories about people pulling hoaxes...on themselves.

radio_episode.title: In Dog We Trust
radio_episode.description: Stories of dogs and cats and other animals that live in our homes. Exactly how much are they caught up in everyday family dynamics? We answer this question and others.

radio_episode.title: Dolls
radio_episode.description: Stories of what people are playing at when they play with dolls.

radio_episode.title: Crush
radio_episode.description: Stories of love in its earliest stage. Crushes: what's terrible about them, what's great about them and how they can overshadow real love for some people.

radio_episode.title: Primary
radio_episode.description: Today's program is made all of stories from the New Hampshire primary. Voters want to find a candidate who inspires them. Candidates want to inspire. So where's the system failing? Why do most of us feel like the system doesn't produce anyone inspiring? We hear stories that answer why. We hear from voters who've found candidates they love. And we hear what those voters are seeing that the rest of us aren't.

radio_episode.title: Kids As Adults
radio_episode.description: Stories of kids trying to act like adults—some by choice—some because they're forced to.

radio_episode.title: Bedside Diplomacy
radio_episode.description: In the hospital, we give up our normal schedule and sleep patterns; we give up our normal food and clothing; we're in a place that has its own rules and its own language and its own customs.

radio_episode.title: The Angels Wanna Wear My Red Suit
radio_episode.description: A special Christmas edition of our show, with stories about Santa Claus—the many many different versions of Santa Claus. It was in America, in New York, that people started believing in the modern idea of Santa—a guy who comes down the chimney with a sack of goodies. But America has invented a few other Santas as well.

radio_episode.title: A Teenager's Guide to God
radio_episode.description: Oh faithless and perverse generation? How long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you?—Matthew 17.

radio_episode.title: Urban Nature
radio_episode.description: Stories of nature creeping into man-made environments. Of nature sneaking in places where its very presence is a rebuke to the notion that we as a species have things under control.

radio_episode.title: Poultry Slam 1999
radio_episode.description: For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it's our annual program about turkeys, chickens, fowl of all types, and their mysterious hold over our imaginations. This show includes favorite stories from previous Poultry Shows, and some new stories.

radio_episode.title: Where Words Fail
radio_episode.description: One reason we tell stories is to explain things to ourselves that cannot, in the end, always be explained. When someone we're close to dies, we struggle for a way to get our minds around the fact of their absence. And often—the stories we invent aren't quite up to the job. In this week's show, people struggle to invent words adequate to cope with death.

radio_episode.title: Sentencing
radio_episode.description: We've all heard occasional news stories about how some of the drug laws enacted in the last 15 years may have gone too far. First time offenders get locked up for decades. Judges—even Republican appointees—say that mandatory minimum sentences prevent them from making fair rulings. But have sentences really gone too far?

radio_episode.title: Barbara
radio_episode.description: We hear the story of one African-American single mother. Barbara Clinkscales recorded her family's life over the course of seven months for This American Life. Her life defies—or makes irrelevant—most of our typical notions of inner-city, black single mothers.

radio_episode.title: Invisible Worlds
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who are trying to make invisible worlds visible, and what happens when you make them visible.

radio_episode.title: Family Business
radio_episode.description: Stories of family businesses, and what happens when the tension of family dynamics collides with the pressure of capitalist market forces.

radio_episode.title: Ghosts of Elections Past
radio_episode.description: Stories of political idealists, stories designed to provide some small sense of hope about American politics. Most of these were first broadcast during the 1996 Presidential race.

radio_episode.title: The Real Thing
radio_episode.description: Stories of people drawn to some idea, some picture, some "thing" that they just want to be. How some people imitate this "thing" innocently, some less innocently, and how easy it is to slip from one to the other.

radio_episode.title: The Book That Changed Your Life
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who believe a book changed their life. It's a romantic notion, and one reason we believe it is because we want to believe our lives can be changed by something so simple as an idea — or a set of ideas contained in a book.

radio_episode.title: You Are Here
radio_episode.description: Three stories, three people, and three sets of maps. Stories of people trying to figure out where they are in the world in the most literal and least literal ways possible. We explore what it's like to be lost—how we all struggle in that moment not to give ourselves over to fear but try to enjoy it.

radio_episode.title: Allure of Crime
radio_episode.description: We think of crime as a kind of monolithic, menacing presence. But there are many kinds of crimes and many kinds of criminals. Through our crimes, we express who we are. Today we hear of three different criminals and three different kinds of crimes.

radio_episode.title: We Didn't
radio_episode.description: Stories about what happens when we don't do something. It turns out that not falling in love, not doing our jobs, not spending time with our families is every bit as vivid and complicated an experience as doing something.

radio_episode.title: Sales
radio_episode.description: Consider for a moment all the art forms that began in America: jazz, the blues, musical theater, rock n' roll, phonograph recordings, television, motion pictures, video games. But the art form in which America leads the world—more than any other—is the art of selling. In this show: case examples to prove the point.

radio_episode.title: Father's Day '99
radio_episode.description: For Father's Day, stories about fathers going out of their way to protect their kids, and kids going out of their way to protect their fathers.

radio_episode.title: The Kids Are Alright
radio_episode.description: Stories in which young people take matters into their own hands: Students who become political activists, students who pull pranks, violent students. Broadcast for the tenth anniversary of the crackdown at Tiananmen Square.

radio_episode.title: Away From Home
radio_episode.description: Stories of people going home to places they've never been before.

radio_episode.title: Advice
radio_episode.description: A program taped before live audiences in Seattle (thanks to public radio station KUOW) and at HBO's U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen. A taxonomy of different kinds of advice—and stories that illustrate why advice is so rarely taken.

radio_episode.title: Four Corners
radio_episode.description: There's a tourist monument called Four Corners, where Arizona, Colorado, Utah and New Mexico meet. In this episode, we try to tell the story of life in America through portraits of life on four different corners, in four different states across the nation.

radio_episode.title: Pimp Anthropology
radio_episode.description: This entire show is devoted to just one story. A former pimp tells how he and three childhood friends became pimps in the 1970s in Oakland, California. He explains all the elaborate "rules of the game" among pimps and prostitutes of that era. He didn't have the stomach for the violence of pimping, and failed as a pimp because of that. Tamar Brott reports.

radio_episode.title: Do-Gooders
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to do good: Why they often fail and why they occasionally succeed.

radio_episode.title: Apocalypse
radio_episode.description: Stories of the end of the world. More people believe it's more imminent than you probably realize.

radio_episode.title: Welcome to America
radio_episode.description: Stories of people moving to this country: what they see and hear about America that those of us who were born here don't necessarily see.

radio_episode.title: High Cost of Living
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who choose not to live every moment to the fullest or smell the roses, and instead choose to withdraw from life, to make themselves numb.

radio_episode.title: Valentine's Day '99
radio_episode.description: For Valentine's Day, stories of impossible love and heartbreak.

radio_episode.title: Twentieth Century Man
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Keith Aldrich with his daughter, Gillian Aldrich.
radio_episode.description: One thing that makes our country different from most others is this idea that you can re-create yourself as someone you'd prefer to be...sell everything off, head out west, start a new life.  But what happens if you're too good at it?  At throwing everything out and starting over?

radio_episode.title: Be Careful Who You Pretend to Be
radio_episode.description: Three stories of people pretending to be something they're not, and what happens to them.

radio_episode.title: Lockup
radio_episode.description: With the number of prisoners in the United States rising rapidly, we present stories of their lives and the lives of their families and children.

radio_episode.title: What You Lookin' At?
radio_episode.description: Stories about seeing and being seen. Taped before a live audience in Town Hall in New York City in December 1998, this was a co-production with WNYC New York, featuring live music by the pop band They Might Be Giants and the This American Life Orchestra.

radio_episode.title: You Gonna Eat That?
radio_episode.description: The family table is stage on which many family dramas are played out. We hear three stories...of three families...at three meals.

radio_episode.title: Poultry Slam 1998
radio_episode.description: For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it's our annual program about turkeys, chickens, and fowl of all types.

radio_episode.title: First Day
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Paint-by-number kit, previously sold in the This American Life store.
radio_episode.description: Stories of the first day on the job, the first day in a relationship, the first day in school. On the first day, any first day, we're expected to live by the rules and customs of the culture we're entering, but we don't know those rules and customs just yet.

radio_episode.title: Last Words
radio_episode.description: Stories of people's last words before death. Their one last shot at figuring things out, summing things up. One last moment of asserting the fact of our existence, at the moment of our annihilation.

radio_episode.title: Windfall
radio_episode.description: What happens when you suddenly strike it rich. And the power money has over our lives, for good and bad.

radio_episode.title: Ladies and Germs
radio_episode.description: Germs, and how they make us leave the world of rational thinking.

radio_episode.title: Adventures in the Simple Life
radio_episode.description: I thought this was supposed to be easy. Tales from the simple life.

radio_episode.title: Mapping
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Denis Wood's map of phone, cable, and power lines in Boylan Heights.
radio_episode.description: Five ways of mapping the world. One story about people who make maps the traditional way — by drawing things we can see. And other stories about people who map the world using smell, sound, touch, and taste. The world redrawn by the five senses.

radio_episode.title: Notes on Camp
radio_episode.description: Stories of summer camp. People who love camp say that non-camp people simply don't understand what's so amazing about camp. In this program, we attempt to bridge the gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people.

radio_episode.title: Truth and Lies at Age Ten
radio_episode.description: Two stories of children lying to themselves and others. A woman who'd been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis talks about the lies she told herself as a child. And Dan Gediman tells the story of how he was cast in the public TV show Zoom, which aired from 1972 to 1979, at the age of ten. Then he was cut from the cast before the show ever went on the air. So for years, he lied about it. He let friends believe he was on Zoom.

radio_episode.title: Trail of Tears
radio_episode.description: For the July 4th holiday weekend, writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister re-trace the "Trail of Tears" — the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson.

radio_episode.title: Father's Day '98
radio_episode.description: For this Father's Day, stories in which fathers and their kids sit down and try to have an honest moment together. And stories about fathers who aren't close with their kids.

radio_episode.title: Take A Negro Home
radio_episode.description: Two stories of people who try to cross the color line — and why it's still so hard. We hear the story of a failed interracial marriage and the story of a teenager from a poor inner city neighborhood (Cedric Jennings, pictured) who ends up at an Ivy League University — and how he barely survives there.

radio_episode.title: Music Lessons
radio_episode.description: What's frustrating about music lessons, what's miraculous about them, and what they actually teach us. This show was recorded in front of a live audience at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, with help from KQED-FM, during the 1998 Public Radio Conference in San Francisco.

radio_episode.title: Scenes from A Transplant
radio_episode.description: An NPR reporter leaves her three-year-old son and heads to Omaha—for cancer treatment—a last chance to save her life. After years of covering stories about medicine, Rebecca Perl enters the hospital as a patient. She moves from the world of healthy people into the world of sick ones. What she sees and what she learns.

radio_episode.title: Road Trip!
radio_episode.description: With all the American movies and songs and books about the joy of the open road, it's hard for an American to take just a normal road trip without huge expectations.

radio_episode.title: Niagara
radio_episode.description: During this hour, a special edition of our show: Stories about Niagara Falls, half of them from documentary producer Alix Spiegel, who went to the Falls and interviewed people living there; and half from playwright David Kodeski, who grew up in the town of Niagara Falls.

radio_episode.title: Radio
radio_episode.description: For the 100th episode of This American Life, a radio show about the pleasures of radio. About what makes radio so great ... and what makes it so terrible.

radio_episode.title: I Enjoy Being A Girl, Sort Of
radio_episode.description: Variations on what it means to be a girl and what it means to be a woman.

radio_episode.title: Throwing the First Punch
radio_episode.description: Stories about what it means to be a person who throws the first punch ... and how hard it is to give up.

radio_episode.title: Death to Wacky
radio_episode.description: An assault on the idea of wackiness. And then, an appreciation of wackiness, and an analysis of wackiness in American culture. Thirteen ways to describe wackiness.

radio_episode.title: Pinned by History
radio_episode.description: People who left their private lives and were seized by some huge historical moment.

radio_episode.title: Monogamy
radio_episode.description: How should we react to people who are in non-monogamous relationships? What should we think of these struggles with monogamy?

radio_episode.title: How To
radio_episode.description: What happens during a "how-to," and what our how-to's say about us. Most how-to's promise that you'll not only learn skills, you'll be transformed.

radio_episode.title: Valentine's Day '98
radio_episode.description: Stories about couples that all take place decades after that moment their eyes first meet.

radio_episode.title: Leave the Mask On
radio_episode.description: Stories about those moments when someone tries to tell you a little bit more about themselves than you'd really rather know.

radio_episode.title: Escape the Box
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to escape the box of their own lives, and create new lives.

radio_episode.title: Telephone
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Illustration of an early telephone set from Principales Découvertes Et Inventions Dans Les Sciences, Les Arts Et L'industrie (1880) by French journalist and encyclopedist Adolphe Bitar
radio_episode.description: Stories of who we are on the phone, of things we learn on the phone, and of things that happen on the phone that don't happen anywhere else.

radio_episode.title: Sibling Rivalry
radio_episode.description: Stories about people who are destined to fight: brothers and sisters.

radio_episode.title: Numbers
radio_episode.description: Numbers lie. Numbers cover over complicated feelings and ambiguous situations. In this week's show, stories of people trying to use numbers to describe things that should not be quantified.

radio_episode.title: A Very Special Sedaris Christmas
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Cover of David Sedaris' book.
radio_episode.description: Stories from David Sedaris's book of Christmas stories, Holidays on Ice, read onstage by David, Julia Sweeney and actor Matt Malloy.

radio_episode.title: How to Take Money from Strangers
radio_episode.description: Two stories of how to get money from strangers. In both stories, the money is made by people who make the strangers feel good about themselves and about their nation.    NOTE: This episode originally included a story by reporter Stephen Glass, which we have removed because of questions about its truthfulness. This story is included in the transcript only for reference.

radio_episode.title: Poultry Slam 1997
radio_episode.description: Humans have turned chicken and turkey into what we want them to be. Which means that chickens and turkeys are a mirror of ourselves.

radio_episode.title: Harold
radio_episode.description: A parable of politics and race in America. The story of Chicago's first black mayor, Harold Washington, told two decades after his death. Washington died on November 25, 1987.

radio_episode.title: One of Us
radio_episode.description: Stories of outsiders who want to be insiders, and vice versa.

radio_episode.title: Haunted
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who are haunted, not by ghosts or phantoms, but by other people.

radio_episode.title: Guns
radio_episode.description: Americans who love their guns...and the Americans who love them.

radio_episode.title: Running After Antelope
radio_episode.description: Stories of people engaged in a battle with nature — a battle they don't stand much chance of winning. Most of the show is Scott Carrier's story of trying for twelve years to chase down and catch an antelope by foot.

radio_episode.title: Stuck in the Wrong Decade
radio_episode.description: People stuck in the wrong decade — or simply carrying a lot of the props from another decade.    NOTE: This episode originally included a story by reporter Stephen Glass (no relation to Ira), which we have removed because of questions about its truthfulness. This story is included in the transcript only for reference.

radio_episode.title: How Bad Is Bad?
radio_episode.description: How bad is bad enough to count? To go to hell?

radio_episode.title: Pray
radio_episode.description: Can the secular world and the religious world understand each other?

radio_episode.title: Mob
radio_episode.description: The mob as portrayed in movies, and as it is in real life. And its hold over us.

radio_episode.title: Kindness of Strangers
radio_episode.description: Stories of the kindness of strangers and where it leads. Also, the unkindness of strangers and where that can lead. All of today's stories take place in the city most people think of as the least kind city in America: New York.

radio_episode.title: Conventions
radio_episode.description: What happens when people with one common interest gather in monstrous, fluorescent -lit halls for the weekend? Sometimes they drive each other crazy, sometimes they fall in love.

radio_episode.title: Blame It on Art
radio_episode.description: The darker side of the art world: petty jealousies, competitiveness, failure. And also what's so great about art.

radio_episode.title: Trek
radio_episode.description: An idiosyncratic first-person travelogue about race relations and tourism from radio producer Rich Robinson and television producer Josh Seftel. Their radio story is about a trip they took to the new South Africa. Rich Robinson is black. Josh Seftel is white. The interracial pair travel through the still mostly-segregated society and have very different opinions about what they see, especially when it comes to some distant relatives of Josh's in South Africa.

radio_episode.title: Defying Sickness
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to do exactly what the doctors say they can't — or shouldn't.

radio_episode.title: Other People's Mail
radio_episode.description: When you read other people's mail, you can't help but try to fill in between the lines. You try to decipher the stories of the people who wrote the letters. We hear four stories of people who read other people's mail, and what happens to them once they get caught up in these other lives.

radio_episode.title: Dream House
radio_episode.description: How many of our parents move to some place — some dream house — with some vision of a new life in the new place, and move the family with them, hoping it works out for the kids. Three stories on this theme.

radio_episode.title: Lincoln's Second Inaugural
radio_episode.description: A show for July 4th weekend. We begin with perhaps the most moving, poetic inaugural speech in American history, and look at its legacy today. In his second inaugural address, Lincoln wondered aloud why God saw fit to send the slaughter of the Civil War to the United States. His conclusion: that slavery was a kind of original sin for the United States, for both North and South, and all Americans had to do penance for it.

radio_episode.title: Your Dream, My Nightmare
radio_episode.description: Could it be more obvious? Stories in which someone's dream is someone else's nightmare. All of us get into these situations with strangers, with the people we love most, with our own parents, with our children.

radio_episode.title: Tales from the Net
radio_episode.description: Are people having experiences on the Internet they wouldn't have anywhere else? Several weeks ago, This American Life invited listeners to help answer that question.

radio_episode.title: Who's Canadian?
radio_episode.description: Notes and stories about the Canadians among us. Are they in fact any different from red-blooded Americans? They claim they're not. Skeptical Americans put their position to the test.

radio_episode.title: Summer
radio_episode.description: Stories for the start of summer. We want summer to be this wonderful break, but so often it fails to deliver. We hear Ron Carlson's short story about a summer job delivering tanks of oxygen to the infirm, Scott Carrier takes a river vacation, and more.

radio_episode.title: One Thing
radio_episode.description: People whose lives are organized around one thing.

radio_episode.title: Something for Nothing
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Illustration by Chris Ware, inspired by "Hands on a Hardbody"
radio_episode.description: Stories of people trying to get rich quick or otherwise make something for nothing. As everyone knows, there's no such thing as something for nothing. You always pay a price.

radio_episode.title: Fiasco!
radio_episode.description: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong. When you leave the normal realm of human error, fumble, mishap, and mistake and enter the territory of really huge breakdowns. Fiascos. Things go so awry that normal social order collapses. This week's show is a philosophical inquiry in the nature of fiascos — perhaps the first ever.

radio_episode.title: Business of Death
radio_episode.description: Usually we talk about death as a tragedy, a mystery, a hard-to-comprehend fact of life. But in addition to all that, for all sorts of people it's also ... a job.

radio_episode.title: Fire
radio_episode.description: Stories about people who are not afraid of fire, though perhaps they should be.

radio_episode.title: Small Towns
radio_episode.description: Stories of small town life: the claustrophobia and freedom people feel in small towns, the yearning people feel in small towns. And three teenagers in one of the harshest urban environments explain how the public housing projects are like a small town.

radio_episode.title: Delivery
radio_episode.description: Stories about the delivery business and the people in it. UPS men, bike messengers, FedEx dispatchers.     NOTE: This episode originally included a story by reporter Stephen Glass, which we have removed because of questions about its truthfulness. This story is included in the transcript only for reference.

radio_episode.title: Name Change
radio_episode.description: Stories of people changing their name — some to create a new identity, some to con people. Name changes are particularly American stories: they're the dream of starting over with a clean slate. They're Ellis Island and 12-step programs, the move westward and self help, Marilyn Monroe and Malcolm X and the Artist Formerly Known as Prince, all rolled up in one.

radio_episode.title: Three Women and the Sex Industry
radio_episode.description: A few months ago, radio producer Sandy Tolan was supposed to do a documentary about strippers with an aspiring writer — and stripper — named Susan. A few days before they were to begin working together, Susan disappeared, presumed dead.

radio_episode.title: Sinatra
radio_episode.description: Stories, tributes, and attempts to understand the Chairman of the Board.

radio_episode.title: Valentine's Day '97
radio_episode.description: For Valentine's Day, stories about our parents falling in love. And troubles with their love. From Hilton Als, Scott Carrier, Julie Showalter, a magazine column called Men My Mother Dated and others. The idea for this show was inspired by Delmore Schwartz's classic 1937 work of American fiction about his parents' courtship: In Dreams Begin Responsibilities and Other Stories.

radio_episode.title: Edge of Sanity
radio_episode.description: Stories about the border between mental health and mental illness.

radio_episode.title: Animals Die, People Ponder
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who handle dead animals. Don't worry — it's not as gross as it sounds. In fact, not disgusting at all. A story by George Saunders about an animal control man who falls in unrequited love. A woman who studies illuminated manuscripts, whose pages look like paper but are in fact animals. And other stories.

radio_episode.title: Shoulda Been Dead
radio_episode.description: Kevin Kelly was in Jerusalem. For reasons too complicated to go into here, he ended up sleeping on the spot where Jesus was supposedly crucified. After Kevin awoke, the thought came into his head: Live as if you'll die in six months. So he did.

radio_episode.title: Animals
radio_episode.description: Stories about the animalness of animals, the irreducible ways in which they are not human.

radio_episode.title: Justice
radio_episode.description: Kitty Felde shows a side of the Yugoslav War Crimes Trials that hasn't been discussed anywhere: a portrait of Americans at the International Tribunal. And other stories.

radio_episode.title: Christmas and Commerce
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Illustration by Chris Ware, inspired by the "Christmas Freud" story
radio_episode.description: Stories about the intersection of Christmas and retail, including David Sedaris's story "Santaland Diaries," which was first broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition many years ago in a much shorter version.

radio_episode.title: Sissies
radio_episode.description: Though being gay no longer has much of a stigma in some parts of the country, being a sissy still does — even among gay men. In this show we have a number of surprising and unusual stories of sissies, their families, and why people still get so upset about them.

radio_episode.title: Media Fringe
radio_episode.description: Four stories about people struggling at the fringes of our nation's media/music/infotainment industry.

radio_episode.title: Poultry Slam 1996
radio_episode.description: In the midst of the five biggest poultry-consumption weeks of the year—the five weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas, when Americans consume one-fourth of all the turkey they eat in a year—This American Life presents stories about turkeys, chickens, ducks, and fowl of all kinds.

radio_episode.title: Faustian Bargains
radio_episode.description: Inspired by a spate of new Chicago stage adaptations of the Faust story, This American Life brings you stories of people who made a deal with the devil.

radio_episode.title: Get Over It!
radio_episode.description: Three stories of people trying to forget the past and move on.

radio_episode.title: Politics
radio_episode.description: More stories of the election you can't hear anywhere else.

radio_episode.title: Lessons
radio_episode.description: Stories from acclaimed storyteller Spalding Gray and others.

radio_episode.title: Halloween
radio_episode.description: This week: A show for Halloween. Stories of things that are supposed to be scary, but aren't.

radio_episode.title: Simulated Worlds
radio_episode.description: Simulated worlds, Civil war reenactments, wax museums, simulated coal mines, fake ethnic restaurants, an ersatz Medieval castle and other re-created worlds that thrive all across America. (4 minutes)

radio_episode.title: The Job That Takes Over Your Life
radio_episode.description: Radio producer Scott Carrier quit his job at a low moment in his life. His wife left him and took the kids. And he got a job interviewing schizophrenics for some medical researchers. After doing it a while, he began to wonder if he was a schizophrenic himself. And more stories.

radio_episode.title: Letters
radio_episode.description: Host Ira Glass and playwright David Hauptschein took out advertisements in Chicago inviting people to come to a small theater with letters they've received, sent or found.

radio_episode.title: Fall Clearance Sale
radio_episode.description: Evocative, funny, emotional stories collected over the last few months that haven't fit into any of our regular "theme" shows.

radio_episode.title: Democratic Convention
radio_episode.description: Unusual stories from the 1996 Democratic Convention in Chicago, with scenes and moments not documented elsewhere.

radio_episode.title: A Night at the Wiener Circle
radio_episode.description: Host Ira Glass spent a Saturday night — from 9:00 p.m. until dawn the next morning — at one of the most frenetic, joyous, efficient, angry, boisterous hot dog stands in the nation: Chicago's own Wiener Circle.

radio_episode.title: Republican Convention
radio_episode.description: Unusual stories about day-to-day life at the Republican Convention.

radio_episode.title: When You Talk About Music
radio_episode.description: Stories of people whose lives are transformed by music.

radio_episode.title: Obsession
radio_episode.description: Stories of obsession and compulsion. What happens when a little idea starts to control you. Co-hosted by Paul Tough.

radio_episode.title: Bob Dole
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics
radio_episode.description: Unusual perspectives on the presumptive Republican nominee.

radio_episode.title: Detectives
radio_episode.description: Writer David Sedaris recalls the days when his mother and sister played armchair detective — until a very odd crime wave hit within their own home. Plus, host Ira Glass goes out on surveillance with a real-life private eye.

radio_episode.title: The Cruelty of Children
radio_episode.description: Stories about kids being mean to each other... including a mysterious handbook for bullies, a surprising experiment conducted by a teacher who wants to make kids be nice, and a story of youthful backstabbing told by David Sedaris.

radio_episode.title: Father's Day '96
radio_episode.photo_credit: Photo: Illustration of Mr. Loh by Chris Ware
radio_episode.description: Ira's own father Barry Glass co-hosts this special father's day edition of the show.

radio_episode.title: Basketball
radio_episode.description: A set of documentary stories, radio essays and monologues about basketball, the Chicago Bulls, and their grip on Chicagoans' hearts and lives during the NBA Playoffs.

radio_episode.title: Teenaged Girls
radio_episode.description: Stories of girls who have to figure out how they're going to act when the ground rules are constantly shifting.

radio_episode.title: Drama Bug
radio_episode.description: Stories of the people who fall for a life in the theater.

radio_episode.title: Adult Children
radio_episode.description: Stories of the difficult relationships between parents and their grown children, including two long stories from Sandra Tsing Loh about her father.

radio_episode.title: Factions
radio_episode.description: A show about something most people have gone through. Friends get together to start a business, start a church, do political action together. And after a while, they start fighting and split up. We hear three true stories.

radio_episode.title: From A Distance
radio_episode.description: Stories of hero worship, of people admiring someone from afar, and trying to get closer to them.

radio_episode.title: Rich Guys
radio_episode.description: Men who had comfortable, decent lives, yet decided to do something wild and eccentric with their lives instead.

radio_episode.title: Liars
radio_episode.description: April first is the one day of the year when we're allowed to enjoy deceiving others. But April Fools' Day is for amateur deceivers. The real pros are the people who can't control their lying, who lie without even knowing what the truth is.

radio_episode.title: Name Change / No Theme
radio_episode.description: Our first show as This American Life.

radio_episode.title: Economy
radio_episode.description: Stories of politics, the economy, and the big picture.

radio_episode.title: Dawn
radio_episode.description: Writer Jack Hitt goes on a search for a mysterious neighbor from his childhood in Charleston, South Carolina, and stumbles onto an epic story of the Old South, the New South, gender confusion, Chihuahuas, and changing values in American journalism.

radio_episode.title: Accidental Documentaries
radio_episode.description: What unites these stories on the surface is that they're all made from old tapes, recordings found in attics and thrift stores. What unites them under that surface — and not far under it — is that they all end up being stories about fathers and the legacies that fathers leave their children.

radio_episode.title: Love
radio_episode.description: Explorations of the dream of true love ... and the difficulties with achieving and maintaining that dream.

radio_episode.title: Animals
radio_episode.description: Stories about the animalness of animals, the irreducible ways in which they are not human.

radio_episode.title: Enemies
radio_episode.description: A story of a friendship between two adolescent boys that was destroyed through the manipulative acts of one of them.

radio_episode.title: Double Lives
radio_episode.description: People living their lives, just like the rest of us. Plus an extra life.

radio_episode.title: Julia Sweeney
radio_episode.description: When comedienne Julia Sweeney and her brother both got cancer, she decided to tell the story the best way she knew how: in a comedy club. It might seem like a strange choice, but what resulted is halfway between standup comedy and true-life diary entries.

radio_episode.title: New Year
radio_episode.description: Stories that reflect back on 1995.

radio_episode.title: Quitting
radio_episode.description: Stories of people who quit everything in their lives that they hated—and what happened to them afterwards.

radio_episode.title: Anger and Forgiveness
radio_episode.description: Stories that reveal the societal "trend" toward anger and away from genuine forgiveness.

radio_episode.title: Vacations
radio_episode.description: Stories about vacations gone awry—or perhaps vacations that never should have happened.

radio_episode.title: Poultry Slam 1995
radio_episode.description: Stories decrying the wonders of turkeys, chickens, and other fowl.

radio_episode.title: Small Scale Sin
radio_episode.description: Small-scale stories on the nature of small-scale sin.

radio_episode.title: New Beginnings
radio_episode.description: Our program's very first broadcast.

extra.title: Early Sedaris Stories: 3 of 4 -- Valentine's Day
extra.description: In this diary David talks about love, and about the word "love" [(C) 1993, NPR(R), Commentary by David Sedaris originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on February 15, 1993, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: This American Life: Behind the Scenes -- Clip 5 of 5
extra.description:
On September 16th 2009, most of the staff of This American Life appeared on stage in New York City to discuss how the show is put together. 

In this clip the staff talks about the stories their parents pitch, and Ira reflects on the success of the show.

extra.title: This American Life: Behind the Scenes -- Clip 4 of 5
extra.description:
On September 16th 2009, most of the staff of This American Life appeared on stage in New York City to discuss how the show is put together. 

In this clip the staff answer audience questions and discuss some of the stories that will probably never make it on the air.

extra.title: This American Life: Behind the Scenes -- Clip 3 of 5
extra.description:
On September 16th 2009, most of the staff of This American Life appeared on stage in New York City to discuss how the show is put together. 

In this clip production manager Seth Lind talks about a small detail that almost turned the 2008 This American Life live show into a fiasco.

extra.title: This American Life: Behind the Scenes -- Clip 2 of 5
extra.description:
On September 16th 2009, most of the staff of This American Life appeared on stage in New York City to discuss how the show is put together. 

In this clip Ira and the staff talk about the show's popular contributors. And senior producer Julie Snyder tells the story of how we started doing economics coverage.

extra.title: This American Life: Behind the Scenes -- Clip 1 of 5
extra.description:
On September 16th 2009, most of the staff of This American Life appeared on stage in New York City to discuss how the show is put together. 

In this clip longtime producer Nancy Updike talks about the early days of the show, including some entertaining production emergencies.

extra.title: "Thanks, I'm Here All Eighth Grade."
extra.description: Jonathan Goldstein did this story for our TV show, but it had to be cut for time. It's about kids learning to do stand up comedy, and has never been available online until now.

extra.title: Mike Birbiglia: "D.U. Why?!!!"
extra.description: A sample from the 2009 show we did onstage and beamed into movie theaters around the country "Return to the Scene of the Crime." You can get the whole show on DVD at thisamericanlife.org.

extra.title: Torey Malatia Speaks!
extra.description: This American Life production manager Seth Lind interviews Torey Malatia, to learn how Torey feels about being maligned at the end of each episode, and whether people are ever surprised that he's a real person.

extra.title: Early Sedaris Stories: 4 of 4 -- Giantess
extra.description: In this diary David talks about writing for a magazine that published erotic fiction about women who are between 10 and 75 feet tall. [(C) 1993, NPR(R), Commentary by David Sedaris originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on May 6, 1993, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: Early Sedaris Stories: 1 of 4 - Santaland
extra.description: David's first radio stories were produced in the early '90s by Ira Glass for NPR's Morning Edition.  David was still an unpublished writer, and so completely unknown that Renee Montagne mispronounced his name in his first appearance. These stories were presented as excerpts from David's diaries.  In this first diary, he talks about working as a Christmas elf at Macy's. [(C) 1992, NPR(R), Commentary by David Sedaris originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on December 23, 1992, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: Krulwich Cartoon
extra.description: For the opening of an episode in our second season of TV, "Every Marriage Is a Courtroom," artist Chris Ware and animator John Kuramoto made this cartoon, set to an interview Ira did with Robert Krulwich. You can get the entire episode on iTunes.

extra.title: Kids with Cameras
extra.description: For the opening of the third episode of our first season of TV, "The Cameraman," artist Chris Ware and animator John Kuramoto set an interview to pictures. You can get the entire episode on iTunes.

extra.title: Quimby the Mouse
extra.description: Artist Chris Ware and animator John Kuramoto made this cartoon for our 2009 live show "Return To the Scene of the Crime." It answers the question: what happens when a mouse falls in love with a cat head?

extra.title: Lost Buildings
extra.description: Ira writes: In 2004 we put our show onstage and took it on a national tour, and wanted something visual for the audience in the theater. Cartoonist Chris Ware and I collaborated to make this. I did the sound, which I'd perform live onstage. Chris did the slides. This is just an excerpt; you can get the whole thing, plus this beautiful book - yes, a book - that Chris made for it, at thisamericanlife.org.

extra.title: Early Ira Glass Stories: 2 of 3 - Bradley Harrison Pickleshimer
extra.description:
Ira writes: This was an early attempt to do what I ended up doing on This American Life: stories about everyday people that would be little narratives - with a beginning, middle and end - and characters and little plot twists.

[(C) 1990, NPR(R), Commentary by Ira Glass originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on March 22, 1990, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: Early Ira Glass Stories: 1 of 3 - Misunderstood Song Lyrics
extra.description:
Ira writes: I was a producer for All Things Considered for a long time and loved it.  For years, this particular story - which I produced in 1987 - was the most famous thing I'd ever done.  Whenever any reporter wrote about the show, they seemed to choose this segment as the best example of made it so different.

[(C) 1987, NPR(R), Commentary by Ira Glass originally broadcast on NPR's All Things Considered on March 25th, 1987, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: Early Sedaris Stories: 2 of 4 - Smoking
extra.description: In this diary David talks about being a smoker in a non-smoking world. [(C) 1993, NPR(R), Commentary by David Sedaris originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on February 3, 1993, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

extra.title: Terry Gross interviews Ira Glass
extra.description: In 1999, Terry Gross interviewed Ira.  Fresh Air paired this interview with the one where Ira interviewed Terry on a CD they gave away during pledge drives years ago, and gave us permission to include it here.

extra.title: Ira Glass interviews Terry Gross
extra.description: In 2000, Ira interviewed Terry Gross onstage to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Fresh Air.

extra.title: Early Ira Glass Stories: 3 of 3 - Yasuko Akiama
extra.description:
Ira writes: Another one from that same series as Bradley.  Note you never hear me in these early stories.  I was still a pretty terrible radio performer and this was my way around it.

[(C) 1990, NPR(R), Commentary by Ira Glass originally broadcast on NPR's Morning Edition on May 22, 1990, and is used with the permission of NPR. Any unauthorized duplication is strictly prohibited.]

act.title: Prologue.
act.body:
Ira talks about the fact that he never much liked William Burroughs or his writing, just never got 
why Burroughs was this revered figure for some people. Then Ira heard a recent BBC documentary 
about Burroughs and finally understood. Ira says he's going to play the whole documentary on the 
show in honor of what would have been Burroughs 101st birthday this week.
(2 minutes)

act.title: Act One. Burroughs, Part One.
act.body:
Iggy Pop, the documentary's narrator, begins by listing some of the artists and artistic movements 
influenced by Burroughs: Bob Dylan, The Beatles, Steely Dan, Kurt Cobain, Lou Reed; punk, heavy 
metal. We hear from director John Waters on the impact on him of Burroughs' open homosexuality 
and frankness about sex. Others talk about Burroughs' heroin addiction and obsession with guns 
and weapons. Burroughs shot his wife to death in what he said was a terrible accident. 
(35 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. Burroughs, Part Two.
act.body: Iggy Pop picks up the story of Burroughs by explaining "Cut Up" — Burroughs habit of randomly jumbling, repeating and re-assembling words and phrases in his writing. David Bowie and others picked it up. We hear about Burroughs' privileged childhood in St. Louis and his lifelong critique of exactly the world of power and money he grew up in. There's archival footage of Burroughs and others reading his sci-fi stories, and finally Burroughs appearing on Saturday Night Live. (19 minutes)

act.title: Prologue.
act.body: Ira finds a ridiculous comment thread on the Internet about an optical illusion. (3 minutes)

act.title: Act One. Ask Not For Whom The Bell Trolls; It Trolls for Thee.
act.body: Writer Lindy West has been harassed by hundreds of trolls online. But only one ever apologized for his remarks. Lindy began to wonder, could he explain why trolls choose to be so cruel? (21 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. Freedom Fries.
act.body: Recently, This American Life has been getting a lot of hate mail about the young women on our staff — listeners complain about their "vocal fry." Ira investigates the phenomenon. (8 1/2 minutes)

act.title: Act Three. Words of Prey.
act.body: Jeffrey Brodeur worked at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and was put in charge of an Osprey Cam — a live web feed of an osprey nest near his office. Which he thought was just charming — until the mother osprey in the nest began acting strangely. (14 minutes)

act.title: Act Four. Mailer Demon.
act.body: This story, produced by the podcast Reply All (website, iTunes), asks the question — can internet bile ever be helpful? PJ Vogt interviews Paul Ford, a man who programmed a website to deal with his anxiety. The website sends him abusive comments all day long. (6 1/2 minutes)

act.title: Prologue.
act.body:
NPR Science reporters Alix Spiegel and Lulu Miller explain to Ira Glass how they smuggled 
a rat into NPR headquarters in Washington, and ran an unscientific version of a famous 
experiment first done by Psychology Professor Robert Rosenthal. It showed how people’s 
thoughts about rats could affect their behavior. Another scientist, Carol Dweck, explains that 
it’s true for people too: expectations affect students, children, soldiers, in measurable ways.  
(6 minutes)

act.title: Act One. Batman Begins.
act.body: Lulu tells the story of Daniel Kish, who’s blind, but can navigate the world by clicking with his tongue. This gives him so much information about what’s around him, he does all sorts of things most blind people don’t. Most famously, he rides a bike. We learn why he was raised so differently from the way most blind kids are brought up, and how the book The Making of Blind Men by Robert Scott changes everything for him. (25 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. The Dark Knight Rises.
act.body:
Daniel Kish says that through clicking, he forms mental pictures. He actually sees. A 
neuroscientist Lore Thaler explains how that might be possible. Daniel goes on a mission to 
teach other blind people to see the way he does. (23 minutes)

act.title: Prologue.
act.body: This American Life staffers Brian Reed and Bianca Giaever explain to Ira this thing they've found online called WakeUpNow. It's a company but they can't tell exactly what it does, and what its product is. Maybe it's a club? An organization? They find hundreds of enthusiastic videos people have made about it. (5 minutes)

act.title: Act One. Something’s Happening Here and You Don’t Know What It Is.
act.body: Brian and Bianca go to a WakeUpNow conference to try to figure out what the company really is. WakeUpNow does something called "network marketing," which Brian points out, is a very bland term for something completely mind-blowing. The company's Marketing Director Jordan Harris tells Brian and Bianca that what they saw at the conference was not a good measure of what the company is. We also hear from Robert L. Fitzpatrick, who researches network marketing and wrote a book called False Profits; and Damien Lacks, who quit his job to do WakeUpNow. (31 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. Board Games.
act.body: Jacob Goldstein and David Kestenbaum of NPR's Planet Money tell the story of two guys who decided that the CEO of a small tool company was paid too much and wanted to wake people up to that fact - They wanted to cut the CEO's pay. The two people happened to be investors in the tool company. It turns out if you think CEOs are paid too much, it's guys like this with money to invest in stocks that you want on your side. Planet Money is a production of NPR News. (15 minutes)

act.title: Act Three.  Sleep No More.
act.body:
A woman in Springfield Oregon named Angela Jane Evancie tries to get her boyfriend, sleepy grad student Morgan Peach, to wake up during finals week. (3 minutes)

This story was originally broadcast on December 12, 2012.

act.title: Prologue.
act.body:
In New York, like in lots of cities, you can 3-1-1 for help with city services, but there's lots of things that people call in for that operators don't have answers for. And so they improvise. 
(4 minutes)

act.title: Act One. A Marriage of Inconvenience.
act.body:
This next story is about a couple in a relationship that’s unlike the homes either of them grew up in. They’re married. And it’s a prison marriage. They met when the guy in the marriage was 
incarcerated. Reporter Christopher Rhoads tells the story. 
(19 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. Final Rest Stop.
act.body: Tig Notaro is a comedian who’s been on our show before, and last year she went on a tour that was filmed. It was a strange tour. She and a Canadian comic named Jon Dore were going around the country, performing in people’s living rooms and back yards. This was a real tour, booked in advance. Nancy Updike saw the film, and has this story. Tig's "Boyish Girl Interrupted" tour continues in January and February. (4 minutes)

act.title: Act Three. Not All Who Wander Are Lost…But Some Definitely Are.
act.body:
A car is a classic place to realize: "oh, I’m lost." But sometimes the realization of being lost comes first, and the car is the solution. Drive, keep driving, get un-lost. James Spring has this story about a road trip as life plan.
(26 minutes)
act.song_title: He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother

act.title: Prologue.
act.body: When Elna Baker was a kid, she hit her younger sister on the head with a broom, then lied and said it was an accident. So Elna’s dad held a family trial to find the truth. (16 minutes)

act.title: Act One. Tattoos and Memories and Dead Skin on Trial.
act.body: A man posts an ad on Craiglist to find someone to remove his swastika tattoo. Producer Emily Hsiao talked with him about why he got it and why he wants it gone. Emily is an independent producer in Brooklyn. Her story was produced at the Transom Story Workshop in Woods Hole, MA, where you can learn how to make radio. The music was created for this version of the story by Merel van Dijk and Anthony Barilla from the band Merel & Tony. (13 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. This Is Just As Hard for Me as It Is for You.
act.body: Producer Miki Meek tells the story of a man named Will Ream who is trying to figure out what is best for his children, and having some regrets about how things worked out. To tell this story we collaborated with songwriter Stephin Merritt. Stephin scored the story and wrote original songs with lyrics based on quotes from the interviews with Will Ream. You can stream and download them here. (24 minutes)

act.title: Prologue.
act.body: Ira talks to reporters John Diedrich and Raquel Rutlidge, from the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. They got a call from a landlord who said agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives had trashed his place. (9 minutes)

act.title: Act One. WTF, ATF?
act.body: After John and Raquel published their story, the U.S. Congress got involved. And they found some very surprising things happening in other parts of the country. (10 minutes)

act.title: Act Two. The Border Between America and America.
act.body:
If you haven't spent much time in the southwest, you may not know about this, but there are these border patrol checkpoints that are just in the middle of interstate highways and other roads... not at the border. They're as far as a hundred miles away. Reporter Debbie Nathan used to go through these checkpoints regularly when she lived in El Paso in the '80s and '90s.
